drug.name: Leronlimab
drug.description: Leronlimab (PRO-140) is a humanized monoclonal antibody directed against CCR5, a portal that most forms of HIV use to enter immune system cells. Leronlimab is a viral-entry inhibitor that is designed to protect healthy cells from infection.

article.citation: Trkola A, Ketas TJ, Nagashima KA, Zhao L, Cilliers T, Morris L, Moore JP, Maddon PJ, Olson WC: Potent, broad-spectrum inhibition of human immunodeficiency virus type 1 by the CCR5 monoclonal antibody PRO 140. J Virol. 2001 Jan;75(2):579-88.

drug.indication: Investigated for use/treatment in HIV infection.
drug.mechanism-of-action: Leronlimab functions as an entry inhibitor. Leronlimab is a monoclonal antibody which binds to the CCR5 receptor, and interferes with HIV's ability to enter the cell. Leronlimab binds to to CCR5 for over 60 days allowing dosing once every other week.

polypeptide.name: C-C chemokine receptor type 5
polypeptide.specific-function: Receptor for a number of inflammatory CC-chemokines including MIP-1-alpha, MIP-1-beta and RANTES and subsequently transduces a signal by increasing the intracellular calcium ion level. May play a role in the control of granulocytic lineage proliferation or differentiation. Acts as a coreceptor (CD4 being the primary receptor) for HIV-1 R5 isolates.(Microbial infection) Acts as a receptor for human immunodeficiency virus-1/HIV-1.

go-classifier.description: positive regulation of cytosolic calcium ion concentration
release of sequestered calcium ion into cytosol by sarcoplasmic reticulum
